video_title: No Other Laser Can Do This - Rendyr Optic Overview
comment_text: I never post any reviews. I just want people to be aware of how hard it is to get a hold of someone in the company. I have an issue with my laser firing. They told me that usually its the hinge on the machine that collects debris causing the laser not to fire. This worked for maybe 2-3 cuts. I am back to the same problem. Now, the machine no longer fires. The machine homes and "enables laser" but not light when framing the project. When I disable fan and hit start, the machine acts like it is firing. I am following the instructions word for word. I have checked the settings. I have reinstalled the software. Looked the FAQ. I have emailed, called and left messages, and did the online chat.  The team seems really nice. I would just like someone to get in touch with me to trouble shoot. I am willing to send my machine back and have them fix it.   I can't recommend this product because the customer service is subpar. I just wanted to make a gift for my two year old. I am happy to update this if I ever get a hold of them.

video_title: This is the World's Fastest Laser
comment_text:
I‚Äôve had my eye on the Aeon Mira 5S Redline, and I have a few questions regarding my product line that I plan to work with. I want to make sure the machine fits my specific needs, so I‚Äôm hoping you can provide some insights.

1. Can the engraving and cutting height be automatically adjusted to uneven surfaces (e.g., wavy materials)? Ideally, I‚Äôd like a 3D mapping system where I can freely define the measurement points based on the material. I‚Äôd like to set the number of measurement points per square cm or at least define a measurement area to ensure the engraving or 3D map is as accurate as possible.

2. Is there an automated height detection system or any add-ons for soft materials like leaves or flowers, which are difficult to measure with mechanical height detection?

3. What is the noise level of the machine and the exhaust system? I plan to use it in my home, so that‚Äôs important for me.

4. When working with larger materials that are fed through the machine, is it possible for the engraving or cutting to be automatically detected and seamlessly extended? I‚Äôm looking for intelligent software that can adjust the engraving path automatically without needing to manually realign the material.

5. Do you use or recommend any infeed track with a stopper and optional conveyor belt for precise material alignment and consistent movement at the right angle during the process?

6. Is there an intelligent function for engraving multiple identical materials? I would like the machine to detect and optimize the engraving process across multiple pieces with identical designs, to save time and ensure consistent results.

I know that the xTool P2S has most of the features I need, and their software is actually quite good. However, it seems that they may have purchased reviews on Trustpilot, and their customer support has been quite disappointing, so I don‚Äôt fully trust this company.

I‚Äôm also interested in experimenting with inlays in small QR codes, around 30x30mm, where the glass tube CO2 laser might reach its limits. It could be better to go for an RF option, but I‚Äôm not sure if Aeon is the right choice for this. You may have a better idea of what would suit my needs best, considering you‚Äôve tested a larger product range and are up to date with the latest technologies.

I‚Äôm based in Germany, so it would be good if there aren‚Äôt any issues with shipping or customer support, but that‚Äôs mostly optional.

Best regards

comment_text: From what I've gathered, the fully enclosed hobby level diode machines with a camera, air assist and at least 20W of power cost in the 1200-1500 range. This is comparable to lower end CO2 machines. So why not just get the CO2? Well, for one, the cut quality seems to be cleaner with a diode laser, as they usually have smaller kerf and are consistent across the entire work area. The versatility of light cutting up to 15mm and more detailed engraving in a single machine is probably a better option for hobbyists than a small CO2 laser. Or am I wrong and there are CO2 lasers that outperform the engraving quality of diodes?

video_title: Worth it? How the xTool P2 CO2 Laser Stacks Up Against the Competition
comment_text:
I have my P2 a couple of weeks now, and I'm pretty shocked at the quality.

Some stuff was to be expected, like laser misalignment, but serious gantry misaligment and multiple camera issues. I've now spent 90% of my time trying to calibrate the machine, but the more time I spend, the more issues I find. Also, the calibration software they provide is just atrocious.

I would absolutely not buy this machine again. It's clear to me they should not have been shipping this machine yet, there are way too many design issues with it.

video_title: Laser Cutter Showdown: Is Price Worth the Upgrade?‚Å†‚Å†
comment_text: I have the Creality 22W Pro Bundle. My advice to anyone looking at this laser, save up for something better. You find out really quick how limited the machine is and how poorly built it is (wobbly legs, wobbly laser module, cords barely plug in, airflow is horrid making it shut down every 20-30min). After about 2 months I put it under a shelf in my building and haven't touched it since. Creality is an FDM printer company just trying to stay relevant so their support on their lasers are non-existent. Maybe I got a dud, but my friend bought one as well and had a similar experience. I know it's a cheap entry level laser, but I have a hard time supporting a $500+ paperweight.

video_title: Laser Cutter Showdown: Is Price Worth the Upgrade?‚Å†‚Å†
comment_text:
This is not even close to being a fair representation of what each of those lasers can achieve. You can get much, *much* better results from the Creality (and other cheap diode lasers). Either your speed was too low or you power was too high. 

You are *_not_* "definitely going to get a darker mark with the diode", it'll always depend on the power and speed. You can dial them up / down enough that it will barely mark the surface at all. Always start by printing a test grid.

comment_text: Good job Brandon. It's nice to see the OneLaser XRF in "person" and in use. Too bad about no USB port for file upload. I'm 69 years old and bought an Omtech Polar when they first came out (expecting to have fun in my retirement years), but it was too unrefined. I unboxed it, bought a couple "improved" nozzle assemblies, and the Ruika Controller from Cam Edmonds and then never even turned it on! Luckily I was able to sell it for about 80% of what I had in it. So, the OneLaser XRF will be my first laser. I'll be looking forward to your upcoming Thursday Live again. Thanks, Charlie in Central Ohio, but soon to be Central Florida !!

video_title: Watch This Before Buying a Laser Cutter & Engraver in 2025
comment_text: You did miss (or skip) an entire category.... UV laser's.  From what I'm seeing, these are the "IT" laser of today, they can cut glass, engrave glass without masking, and not just the surface of glass, they also do not burn wood or plastic when engraving them, and they engrave thin metals without warping the metal.  But definitely not cheap.

video_title: Pro Desktop Laser at a Budget Price - OneLaser X Series Review
comment_text:
Great reviews, and thanks for the details !  I‚Äôm totally on board with this ranking. 

I had a Polar before‚Äîit worked fine at first, but quickly turned into a disaster. The inside of the machine? Constantly filthy. You have to clean the lens every couple of hours to keep it from getting scorched, and the build quality is‚Ä¶ let‚Äôs just say, not great. I‚Äôve spent so much time on fixing shit, dat I could‚Äôve paid for a whole new machine by now. And customer service? Practically nonexistent. They pass you around, and might call back two weeks later, right after you‚Äôve DIY-fixed the issues.

The P2S was my top pick‚Äînot just for the minor upgrades, but mostly for the bed size (23.6‚Äù x 12‚Äù) and speed. And let‚Äôs be real‚Äîtheir ads are literally everywhere. You can‚Äôt escape them! This company must have piles of cash to burn; it‚Äôs insane how much they‚Äôre pouring into marketing. There are other niche brands like Bolt and Mira, but their bed sizes are too small for my needs, and the pricing is all over the place. Then I saw the ONELASER X, launching right after the P2S, and this new brand checked all my boxes: a bigger bed size (26‚Äù x 14‚Äù), excellent build quality, twice the speed, a clean cabinet design with an enclosed base, and full US-based support., Honestly, I was nervous about going with a new brand, but now I‚Äôm convinced I made the right choice.

Hopefully, OneLaser ships my order on time‚Äîbecause that‚Äôs the important part they can‚Äôt afford to mess up! I mean that seriously.

video_title: Pro Desktop Laser at a Budget Price - OneLaser X Series Review
comment_text:
After watching the product video, I feel confident in this purchase. I really appreciated the clear, up-close views and detailed breakdown, especially around items to consider ordering to be prepared for the machine‚Äôs arrival. I'm glad you suggested getting the air assist, setting up proper ventilation, and preparing for fume management. Thanks for the excellent insights‚ÄîI‚Äôm looking forward to working with this machine!

One of the most innovative features, and something I find especially valuable, is the built-in air quality indicator. This sensor is a game changer, allowing real-time air quality monitoring, which is particularly helpful in a closed room with only a window for ventilation. I had been considering purchasing a separate air quality sensor, so having this integrated feature is a fantastic benefit. Given that a lot of our work can produce strong odors, seeing an indicator for particle levels is very helpful for health and safety.
